message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Epistasis and Adaptation on Fitness Landscapes
Paper Abstract: Epistasis occurs when the effect of a mutation depends on its carrier's genetic background. Despite increasing evidence that epistasis for fitness is common, its role during evolution is contentious. Fitness landscapes, which are mappings of genotype or phenotype to fitness, capture the full extent and complexity of epistasis. Fitness landscape theory has shown how epistasis affects the course and the outcome of evolution. Moreover, by measuring the competitive fitness of sets of tens to thousands of connected genotypes, empirical fitness landscapes have shown that epistasis is frequent and depends on the fitness measure, the choice of mutations for the landscape, and the environment in which it was measured. In this article, I review fitness landscape theory and experiments and their implications for the role of epistasis in adaptation. I discuss theoretical expectations in the light of empirical fitness landscapes and highlight open challenges and future directions toward integrating theory and data and incorporating ecological factors.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Links: [{"title":"Fitness landscape - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fitness_landscape"},{"title":"Evolutionary landscape - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolutionary_landscape"},{"title":"Talk:Fitness landscape - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Fitness_landscape"},{"title":"File:DE Meta-Fitness Landscape (Sphere and Rosenbrock).JPG - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:DE_Meta-Fitness_Landscape_(Sphere_and_Rosenbrock).JPG"},{"title":"File:PSO Meta-Fitness Landscape (12 benchmark problems).JPG - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:PSO_Meta-Fitness_Landscape_(12_benchmark_problems).JPG"},{"title":"NK model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NK_model"},{"title":"Evolutionary algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolutive_algorithm"},{"title":"Error threshold (evolution) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eigen's_paradox"}]

Here are the search results for "Fitness landscape":

## Definition and Overview

In evolutionary biology, fitness landscapes or adaptive landscapes are used to visualize the relationship between genotypes and reproductive success.(no content)In all fitness landscapes, height represents and is a visual metaphor for fitness.

## Key Characteristics

Fitness landscapes are often conceived of as ranges of mountains. There exist local peaks (points from which all paths are downhill, i.e. to lower fitness) and valleys (regions from which many paths lead uphill).(no content)A fitness landscape with many local peaks surrounded by deep valleys is called rugged.(no content)An evolving population typically climbs uphill in the fitness landscape, by a series of small genetic changes, until – in the infinite time limit – a local optimum is reached.

## Applications Beyond Biology

Apart from the field of evolutionary biology, the concept of a fitness landscape has also gained importance in evolutionary optimization methods such as genetic algorithms or evolution strategies. In evolutionary optimization, one tries to solve real-world problems (e.g., engineering or logistics problems) by imitating the dynamics of biological evolution.

## Fitness Seascapes

Fitness seascapes extend the static fitness-landscape model by allowing the adaptive topography to shift through time or across changing environments.

Web search results for query: "Genetic background"

Links: [{"title":"Background selection - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Background_selection"},{"title":"Genomic selection - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Genomic_selection"},{"title":"Shapiro syndrome - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shapiro_syndrome"},{"title":"WIN 55,212-2 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WIN_55,212-2"},{"title":"Rudolph Leibel - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rudolph_Leibel"},{"title":"Race and genetics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Race_and_genetics"},{"title":"Genetics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Genetics"},{"title":"Genetic Studies of Genius - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Genetic_Studies_of_Genius"},{"title":"Rendille people - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rendille_people"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about genetic background:

## Overview

Genetic background, or genomic environment, of a mutation has a significant impact on whether it will be preserved versus lost from a population. In research contexts, genetic background refers to the overall genetic makeup and genetic context in which genes operate.

## In Evolutionary and Population Genetics

Background selection describes the loss of genetic diversity at a locus due to negative selection against deleterious alleles with which it is in linkage disequilibrium. This concept is important because background selection reduces the fixation probability of beneficial mutations, and increases the fixation probability of deleterious mutations.

## In Experimental Research

In laboratory studies, genetic background is an important variable. For example, WIN 55,212-2 reduces voluntary wheel running in laboratory mice, but with effects that depend on both genetic background and sex. This demonstrates that the genetic background of test organisms can significantly influence experimental outcomes.

## In Medical and Trait Research

Genetic background can have an influence on the development of Shapiro syndrome. More broadly, genetic processes work in combination with an organism's environment and experiences to influence development and behavior.

In summary, genetic background refers to the complete genetic composition and genetic context that influences how genes are expressed and how mutations affect an organism or population.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Links: [{"title":"Fitness landscape - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fitness_landscape"},{"title":"Fitness (biology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fitness_(biology)"},{"title":"Inclusive fitness in humans - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inclusive_fitness_in_humans"},{"title":"Evolutionary tradeoff - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolutionary_tradeoff"},{"title":"Evolutionary landscape - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolutionary_landscape"},{"title":"Selection coefficient - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Selection_coefficient"},{"title":"Evolutionary invasion analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolutionary_invasion_analysis"},{"title":"Fecundity selection - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fecundity_selection"}]

I've completed the web search for "Fitness biology evolution." Here's a summary of the key information found:

## Fitness in Evolutionary Biology

Fitness is a quantitative representation of individual reproductive success and is equal to the average contribution to the gene pool of the next generation, made by the same individuals of the specified genotype or phenotype.(no content)J.B.S. Haldane was the first to quantify fitness, in terms of the modern evolutionary synthesis of Darwinism and Mendelian genetics starting with his 1924 paper A Mathematical Theory of Natural and Artificial Selection. Later, W.D. Hamilton introduced the concept of inclusive fitness in 1964 in his paper on The Genetical Evolution of Social Behaviour.

## Fitness Landscapes

In evolutionary biology, fitness landscapes or adaptive landscapes are used to visualize the relationship between genotypes and reproductive success.(no content)An evolving population typically climbs uphill in the fitness landscape, by a series of small genetic changes, until – in the infinite time limit – a local optimum is reached.

## Evolutionary Tradeoffs

An evolutionary tradeoff is a situation in which evolution cannot advance one part of a biological system without distressing another part of it, referring to the process through which a trait increases in fitness at the expense of decreased fitness in another trait.

These concepts form the foundation for understanding how evolution works through natural selection and genetic change.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Web search results for query: "Epistasis genetics"

Links: [{"title":"Epistasis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Epistasis"},{"title":"Epistasis and functional genomics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Epistasis_and_functional_genomics"},{"title":"Additive genetic effects - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Additive_genetic_effects"},{"title":"Labrador Retriever coat colour genetics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Labrador_Retriever_coat_colour_genetics"},{"title":"Population genetics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Population_genetics"},{"title":"Polygene - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Polygene"},{"title":"Hypostatic gene - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hypostatic_gene"},{"title":"Punnett square - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Punnett_square"},{"title":"Association mapping - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Association_mapping"},{"title":"Inclusive composite interval mapping - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inclusive_composite_interval_mapping"}]

Here are the search results for "Epistasis genetics":

## Definition and Overview

Epistasis is a phenomenon in genetics in which the effect of a gene mutation is dependent on the presence or absence of mutations in one or more other genes, respectively termed modifier genes.(no content)In other words, the effect of the mutation is dependent on the genetic background in which it appears.

## Historical Background

The term was first used in 1907 by William Bateson and his collaborators Florence Durham and Muriel Wheldale Onslow.

## Key Distinctions

In this sense, epistasis can be contrasted with genetic dominance, which is aninteraction between alleles at the same gene locus. Additionally, if genes A and B are mutated, and each mutation by itself produces a unique phenotype but the two mutations together show the same phenotype as the gene A mutation, then gene A is epistatic and gene B is hypostatic.

## Types of Epistasis

When the double mutation has a fitter phenotype than expected from the effects of the two single mutations, it is referred to as positive epistasis. Positive epistasis between beneficial mutations generates greater improvements in function than expected. Positive epistasis between deleterious mutations protects against the negative effects to cause a less severe fitness drop.(no content)Conversely, when two mutations together lead to a less fit phenotype than expected from their effects when alone, it is called negative epistasis.

## Practical Example

These individual genes do not act independently of each other, and their interaction in affecting the trait of coat colour is used by biology textbooks to demonstrate the genetic principle of epistasis, where multiple genes react synergistically to affect a single trait. This is exemplified in Labrador Retriever coat color genetics.

Here are the search results for "Epistasis genetics":

## Definition and Overview

Epistasis is a phenomenon in genetics in which the effect of a gene mutation is dependent on the presence or absence of mutations in one or more other genes, respectively termed modifier genes.(no content)In other words, the effect of the mutation is dependent on the genetic background in which it appears.

## Historical Background

The term was first used in 1907 by William Bateson and his collaborators Florence Durham and Muriel Wheldale Onslow.

## Key Distinctions

In this sense, epistasis can be contrasted with genetic dominance, which is aninteraction between alleles at the same gene locus. Additionally, if genes A and B are mutated, and each mutation by itself produces a unique phenotype but the two mutations together show the same phenotype as the gene A mutation, then gene A is epistatic and gene B is hypostatic.

## Types of Epistasis

When the double mutation has a fitter phenotype than expected from the effects of the two single mutations, it is referred to as positive epistasis. Positive epistasis between beneficial mutations generates greater improvements in function than expected. Positive epistasis between deleterious mutations protects against the negative effects to cause a less severe fitness drop.(no content)Conversely, when two mutations together lead to a less fit phenotype than expected from their effects when alone, it is called negative epistasis.

## Practical Example

These individual genes do not act independently of each other, and their interaction in affecting the trait of coat colour is used by biology textbooks to demonstrate the genetic principle of epistasis, where multiple genes react synergistically to affect a single trait. This is exemplified in Labrador Retriever coat color genetics.

Based on the search results, here's an overview of mutation biology:

## Definition

In biology, a mutation is an alteration in the nucleic acid sequence of the genome of an organism, virus, or extrachromosomal DNA.(no content)In contrast to DNA damage, a mutation is an alteration of the base sequence of the DNA.

## How Mutations Occur

Mutations result from errors during DNA or viral replication, mitosis, or meiosis or other types of damage to DNA (such as pyrimidine dimers caused by exposure to ultraviolet radiation), which then may undergo error-prone repair, cause an error during other forms of repair, or cause an error during replication.

## Effects of Mutations

Mutations may or may not produce detectable changes in the observable characteristics (phenotype) of an organism.(no content)Mutations in genes can have no effect, alter the product of a gene, or prevent the gene from functioning properly or completely.

## Biological Significance

Mutations play a part in both normal and abnormal biological processes including: evolution, cancer, and the development of the immune system, including junctional diversity.

## Types of Mutations

The search results describe several specific types, including point mutations, where a single nucleotide base is changed, inserted or deleted from a DNA or RNA sequence, and frameshift mutations caused by indels (insertions or deletions) of a number of nucleotides in a DNA sequence that is not divisible by three.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Links: [{"title":"Genotype - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Genotype"},{"title":"Genotype-first approach - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Genotype-first_approach"},{"title":"Genotype frequency - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Genotype_frequency"},{"title":"Four Core Genotypes mouse model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Four_Core_Genotypes_mouse_model"},{"title":"HCV genotypes - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HCV_genotypes"},{"title":"Genotype–phenotype distinction","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Genotype–phenotype_distinction"},{"title":"Genotyping - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Genotyping"},{"title":"Gene–environment interaction","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gene–environment_interaction"},{"title":"Haplotype estimation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Haplotype_estimation"},{"title":"ABO blood group system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ABO_blood_group_system"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about genotype:

## Definition

The genotype of an organism is its complete set of genetic material.(no content)Genotype can also be used to refer to the alleles or variants an individual carries in a particular gene or genetic location.

## Key Characteristics

In organisms like humans, two full sets of chromosomes are present, meaning each individual has two alleles for any given gene. Based on these alleles, genotypes can be classified:
- If both alleles are the same, the genotype is referred to as homozygous.
- If the alleles are different, the genotype is referred to as heterozygous.

## Genotype vs. Phenotype

A fundamental distinction exists between genotype and phenotype. The "genotype" is an organism's full hereditary information. The "phenotype" is an organism's actual observed properties, such as morphology, development, or behavior.(no content)Genotype contributes to phenotype, the observable traits and characteristics in an individual or organism. However, not all individuals with the same genotype look or act the same way because appearance and behavior are modified by environmental and growing conditions.

## Historical Note

The term genotype was coined by the Danish botanist Wilhelm Johannsen in 1903.

Links: [{"title":"Phenotype - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phenotype"},{"title":"The Extended Phenotype - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Extended_Phenotype"},{"title":"Phenotype (album) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phenotype_(album)"},{"title":"Phenotype (igneous petrology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phenotype_(igneous_petrology)"},{"title":"Human Phenotype Ontology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_Phenotype_Ontology"},{"title":"Phenotype microarray - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phenotype_microarray"},{"title":"Phenotype mixing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phenotype_mixing"},{"title":"Phenotype (clinical medicine) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phenotype_(clinical_medicine)"},{"title":"Genotype–phenotype distinction","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Genotype–phenotype_distinction"},{"title":"Senescence-associated secretory phenotype - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Senescence-associated_secretory_phenotype"}]

Here are the search results for "Phenotype":

## Definition

In genetics, the phenotype is the set of observable characteristics or traits of an organism.(no content)The term covers all traits of an organism other than its genome, including the organism's morphology (physical form and structure), its developmental processes, its biochemical and physiological properties, and all its behavior.

## Genotype vs. Phenotype

The terms "genotype" and "phenotype" were created by Wilhelm Johannsen in 1911.(no content)The "genotype" is an organism's full hereditary information, while the "phenotype" is an organism's actual observed properties, such as morphology, development, or behavior.

## How Phenotypes Develop

An organism's phenotype results from two basic factors: the expression of an organism's unique profile of genes (its genotype) and the influence of environmental factors experienced by that same organism which influence the variable expression of said genes.(no content)Identical twins share the same genotype, since their genomes are identical; but they never have the same phenotype, although their phenotypes may be very similar.

## Applications

The concept of phenotype has various applications across biology. The Human Phenotype Ontology (HPO) was created in 2008 at the Charité to serve as a standardized vocabulary of phenotypic abnormalities that have been seen in human disease, with applications for clinical diagnostics and as a standard vocabulary for clinical databases.

Links: [{"title":"Phenotype - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phenotype"},{"title":"The Extended Phenotype - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Extended_Phenotype"},{"title":"Phenotype (album) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phenotype_(album)"},{"title":"Phenotype (igneous petrology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phenotype_(igneous_petrology)"},{"title":"Human Phenotype Ontology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_Phenotype_Ontology"},{"title":"Phenotype microarray - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phenotype_microarray"},{"title":"Phenotype mixing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phenotype_mixing"},{"title":"Phenotype (clinical medicine) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phenotype_(clinical_medicine)"},{"title":"Genotype–phenotype distinction","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Genotype–phenotype_distinction"},{"title":"Senescence-associated secretory phenotype - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Senescence-associated_secretory_phenotype"}]

Here are the search results for "Phenotype":

## Definition

In genetics, the phenotype is the set of observable characteristics or traits of an organism.(no content)The term covers all traits of an organism other than its genome, including the organism's morphology (physical form and structure), its developmental processes, its biochemical and physiological properties, and all its behavior.

## Genotype vs. Phenotype

The terms "genotype" and "phenotype" were created by Wilhelm Johannsen in 1911.(no content)The "genotype" is an organism's full hereditary information, while the "phenotype" is an organism's actual observed properties, such as morphology, development, or behavior.

## How Phenotypes Develop

An organism's phenotype results from two basic factors: the expression of an organism's unique profile of genes (its genotype) and the influence of environmental factors experienced by that same organism which influence the variable expression of said genes.(no content)Identical twins share the same genotype, since their genomes are identical; but they never have the same phenotype, although their phenotypes may be very similar.

## Applications

The concept of phenotype has various applications across biology. The Human Phenotype Ontology (HPO) was created in 2008 at the Charité to serve as a standardized vocabulary of phenotypic abnormalities that have been seen in human disease, with applications for clinical diagnostics and as a standard vocabulary for clinical databases.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Evolution"

Links: [{"title":"Evolution - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolution"},{"title":"Convergent evolution - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Convergent_evolution"},{"title":"Differential evolution - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Differential_evolution"},{"title":"Evolution (2015 film) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolution_(2015_film)"},{"title":"Human evolution - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_evolution"},{"title":"WWE Evolution (2025) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WWE_Evolution_(2025)"},{"title":"Mitsubishi Lancer Evolution - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mitsubishi_Lancer_Evolution"},{"title":"Evolution (2001 film) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolution_(2001_film)"},{"title":"GE Evolution Series - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/GE_Evolution_Series"},{"title":"Stellar evolution - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stellar_evolution"}]

Here's a summary of the web search results for "Evolution":

## Biological Evolution

Evolution by natural selection is established by observable facts about living organisms: more offspring are often produced than can possibly survive, traits vary among individuals, different traits confer different rates of survival and reproduction, and traits can be passed from generation to generation.(no content)The modern evolutionary synthesis defines evolution as the change over time in genetic variation.(no content)Variation comes from mutations in the genome, reshuffling of genes through sexual reproduction and migration between populations.

### Human Evolution

Over their evolutionary history, humans gradually developed traits such as bipedalism, dexterity, and complex language.(no content)Primates diverged from other mammals about 85 million years ago in the Late Cretaceous period.

## Other Types of Evolution

The search also returned results for several other uses of the term "Evolution":

- **Stellar Evolution**: Stellar evolution is the process by which a star changes over time, with lifetimes ranging from a few million years for the most massive stars to trillions of years for the least massive.

- **Films**: Multiple films titled "Evolution" were found, including a 2001 science fiction comedy and a 2015 French science fiction horror film.

- **Vehicles**: The Mitsubishi Lancer Evolution is a sports sedan and rally car that was manufactured by Mitsubishi Motors from 1992 until 2016.

- **Locomotives**: The Evolution Series is a line of diesel locomotives built by GE Transportation Systems, initially designed to meet the U.S. EPA's Tier 2 locomotive emissions standards.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Adaptation evolution"

Links: [{"title":"Adaptation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptation"},{"title":"Evolution - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolution"},{"title":"Recent human evolution - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Recent_human_evolution"},{"title":"Maladaptation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maladaptation"},{"title":"Lamarckism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lamarckism"},{"title":"Evolutionary tradeoff - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolutionary_tradeoff"},{"title":"Exaptation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Exaptation"},{"title":"Local adaptation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Local_adaptation"},{"title":"Human skeletal changes due to bipedalism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_skeletal_changes_due_to_bipedalism"},{"title":"Theoretical foundations of evolutionary psychology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Theoretical_foundations_of_evolutionary_psychology"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about adaptation and evolution:

## Adaptation in Evolution

Adaptation is the dynamic evolutionary process of natural selection that fits organisms to their environment, enhancing their evolutionary fitness.(no content)In biology, adaptation has three related meanings: firstly, it is the dynamic evolutionary process of natural selection; secondly, it is a state reached by the population during that process.

### How Adaptation Works

Adaptations increase fitness by aiding activities such as finding food, avoiding predators or attracting mates.(no content)Adaptation is one of the two main processes that explain the observed diversity of species, such as the different species of Darwin's finches.

### Historical Context

The scientific theory of evolution by natural selection was conceived independently by two British naturalists, Charles Darwin and Alfred Russel Wallace, in the mid-19th century as an explanation for why organisms are adapted to their physical and biological environments. The theory was first set out in detail in Darwin's book On the Origin of Species.

### Types of Adaptation

Two or more species co-adapt and co-evolve as they develop adaptations that interlock with those of the other species, such as with flowering plants and pollinating insects. Additionally, features evolved for one purpose may be co-opted for a different one, as when the insulating feathers of dinosaurs were co-opted for bird flight.

### Local and Recent Examples

Recent human evolution refers to evolutionary adaptation, sexual and natural selection, and genetic drift within Homo sapiens populations, since their separation and dispersal in the Middle Paleolithic about 50,000 years ago. Examples include human populations living in regions of high altitudes, such as the Tibetan Plateau, Ethiopia, and the Andes benefit from a mutation that enhances the concentration of oxygen in their blood.

message_text:
## Summary

I have successfully completed the analysis of the paper "Epistasis and Adaptation on Fitness Landscapes". Here's what was accomplished:

**Paper Classification:** `survey`
- The paper is a literature review of existing fitness landscape theory and empirical research, with implications for understanding epistasis in adaptation.

**Triples Identified and Extracted (8 total):**

1. **Epistasis** (concept) - Core genetic interaction concept
2. **Mutation** (concept) - Genetic changes analyzed through fitness landscapes
3. **Genotype** (concept) - Genetic composition mapped to fitness
4. **Phenotype** (concept) - Observable traits mapped to fitness
5. **Fitness (biology)** (concept) - Measure of reproductive success
6. **Fitness landscape** (concept) - Central theoretical framework for analyzing epistasis
7. **Evolution** (task) - Process affected by epistasis
8. **Adaptation** (task) - Main focus of how epistasis affects evolutionary outcomes

All triples have been added to `triples_output.json` with:
- Correct Wikipedia URLs (verified via allowed_domains search)
- Appropriate entity types (6 concepts, 2 tasks)
- "uses" relation (appropriate for a survey paper reviewing existing concepts)
- Detailed relevance statements explaining why each entity matters to the paper

**Validation Result:** ✅ **PASSED** - All checks completed successfully.

Sources:
- [Epistasis - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Epistasis)
- [Mutation - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mutation)
- [Genotype - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Genotype)
- [Phenotype - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phenotype)
- [Fitness (biology) - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fitness_(biology))
- [Fitness landscape - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fitness_landscape)
- [Evolution - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolution)
- [Adaptation - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptation)
